titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Miracle House Records
1990-2014
MS 3098
titlestmt.author: Margo Padilla and Larry Weimer

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-25 10:01:34 -0400.

physdesc.extent: in 3 flat boxes, 3 cartons, and 1 flat file folder

did.abstract: This collection contains material from the records of Miracle House, a charity that provided housing, meals, and support services to patients and their caregivers traveling to New York City for medical treatment. The collection consists primarily of records related to fundraising, publicity, and routine business operations.
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized in 2 series:

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Miracle House was founded in 1990 in response to the AIDS crisis to provide affordable temporary housing, free meals and support services to patients and caregivers of people living with AIDS in New York City. In 1997, Miracle House expanded its services to include cancer patients, and in 2005, began to include patients and their caregivers traveling to New York City for any medically related treatment options, procedures, or consultations. Starting with one studio apartment on Manhattan's upper west side, by 2004 Miracle House was operating five apartments, providing a total capacity of 5,475 rooms per year. Citing difficulties with rising costs of the New York City rental market as well as increasing administrative costs, Miracle House ceased operation in 2014.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.
Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

Some formats, such as CDs, floppy disks, and certain digital files, may not be accessible due to file corruption or because the library does not have the equipment or proprietary software necessary to make the information they contain accessible. A full manifest of the individual files comprising the series is available from the reference librarian on request.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The collection should be cited as: Miracle House records, MS 3098, New-York Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed in 2021 by digital archivist Margo Padilla and archivist Larry Weimer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists primarily of records related to fundraising, publicity, and routine business operations such as financial records, annual reports, budgets, and Board meeting minutes. There is also documentation about clinical trials taking place in New York City, client reports and testimonials, newsletters, and shopping lists for the various apartments. There are numerous event files such as photos, flyers, press releases, mailers, sponsor forms, spreadsheets of expenses, letters to donors and other marketing materials.

controlaccess.subject: Fund raising.
Nonprofit Organizations -- New York (State) -- New York.
Publicity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes digital files of records related to fundraising, publicity, and routine business operations such as financial records, annual reports, budgets, and Board minutes. There is also documentation about clinical trials taking place in New York City, client reports and testimonials, newsletters, and shopping lists for the various apartments. The library cannot provide access to all digital files due to file corruption, lack of required software, and/or system specifications. A full manifest of the individual files comprising the series is available from the reference librarian on request.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in two subseries:

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Digital files were delivered by the donor on a 1TB Seagate external hard drive and a duplicative 1TB Seagate internal hard drive. The collection also includes 138 CDs and DVDs. Content from the external drive was transferred to local storage using a Windows instance of Data Accessioner. Content was transferred off the CDs and DVDs using IsoBuster. Data Accessioner created and validated MD5 checksums for each file. A virus scan using ClamWin and Malwarebytes was performed. ClamWin flagged three files and they were removed from the collection. TreeSize was used to identify and remove duplicates and Visual Similarity Duplicate Image Finder was used to identify and remove image duplicates. Temporary and proprietary program files have been removed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Digital content was delivered by the donor on a 1TB Seagate external hard drive and a duplicate 1TB Seagate internal hard drive. Both drives contained all files and directories from the organization's server (56,379 Files, 4,091 Folders). The content consists primarily of records related to fundraising, publicity, and routine business operations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box holds the hard drive and its duplicate from which the above files were extracted. It is retained for back-up purposes only and is restricted from use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains files from CDs and DVDs received from the donor. The content consists primarily of records related to fundraising and publicity, as well as records of routine business operations and file backups. Represented events include Miracle Paddle, Cocktails by the Bay, the Diversity Players of Harlem health fair, Miracle House Mid and Year-End Appeals, and Tea-quila! Party, a fundraiser held in Pines, Fire Island and referred to as Pines throughout the collection. Documents include numerous photos, flyers, press releases, mailers, graphics files for flyers, sponsor forms, spreadsheets of expenses, letters to donors and other marketing materials.

138 discs were received, but 22 discs were not imaged because they were either duplicates or contained copyrighted music. 116 discs were imaged to the ISO format and files were exported from the disk images. The discs were received in one wallet and some loose in one box. Each disc was numbered based on the order starting with the discs in the wallet, and any title or information written on the discs was transcribed to the filename. Each entry in this series represents one disc.

processinfo.p: CD was damaged and files could not be retrieved.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box holds the CDs and DVDs from which the above files were extracted. They were retained for back-up purposes and are restricted from being opened to access the digital files. However, the physical media itself can be requested and examined for context.

physdesc.extent: in 3 flat boxes, 2 cartons, and 1 flat file folder

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes the formats other than digital files in the collection. This principally includes publicity and fundraising event brochures, announcements, invitations, programs, newsletters, and other similar print matter. There are several chronologically sequenced scrapbooks that trace the organization's history from 1990-2010 with photographs, print matter, news articles, and the like. There are guest comment books and many letters of appreciation from guests, extracts of which were often published under the heading "love letters" in Miracle House's newsletters, which are also in the series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged by format.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also includes print-outs of some photos from the 2009-12 galas.

did.unittitle: Fundraising: Bed & Breakfast Campaign, Phase II

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes background on the campaign, talking points, budget, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes, among other documents, brochures with annual reports for 2009 and 2011, publicity pieces tied to the 20th anniversary (2010), and Miracle House's dinner menu at the Pompon Diner and printed directions to various hospitals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Holds the Fall 2004 issue of "At Home" magazine with article "Miracle on 43rd Street" article concerning the design of Miracle House's rooms (pages 99-104).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents related to the proposed acquisition by Miracle House of the former Rice High School building at 74 West 124th Street.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Album includes uncaptioned photographs; they appear to be of various staff events, such as Halloween and other holiday gatherings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 4 cassettes: "Miracle House, Nita Pippins, 4/26/06" in 3 parts on 3 cassettes; and "Miracle House: Hope Away From Home." The videos are restricted from use because of their fragility and N-YHS's lack of equipment to play them. For further information, contact the manuscripts curator at manuscripts@nyhistory.org.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The hard drives are for back-up contingency purposes only and may not be used except by digital processing staff. The files from the drives are available for research; see Series I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box holds the annual scrapbook for 2000 plus a two scrapbook set commemorating the organization's 10th anniversary with photos and other documents spanning 1990-2000.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 2008 scrapbook holds a DVD of the memorial Mass for Helen Sweetser at Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes the following items:
* Photograph of AIDS awareness ribbon composed of roses. Photographer: Susumu Sato, gift from Sato to Miracle House. Signed, dated 1994, numbered 9/40.
* Drawing, front elevation of 156 West 95th Street, initialed G.H., dated 7/5/91.
* Gouache on Mylar, graphic for the Hamptons Hoe-Down, first fundraiser in Hamptons, 1991.
* Photograph, at 1st fundraiser in Pines, 1990.
* 4 posters, with varying content, on the theme of "I believe in miracles."
